report_title: Industry Report on Celebrity and Sports Agents
executive_summary: Celebrity and sports agents generate revenue by managing musicians, actors, athletes, writers and other public figures. Agents' commissions are earned through negotiating employment contracts between clients and employers, with the agent earning a percentage of the agreed deal. Success is driven by the strength of downstream industries, which rely on aggregate consumer spending.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Steady Demand for Sports and Entertainment Strengthens Performance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Sports agents and celebrity managers are highly dependent on steady consumption of sporting events, live performances and athletic participation to ensure a steady cash flow from their clients. Consistent viewership of sports and entertainment content enabled agencies to grow their revenue over the last few years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE PANDEMIC DESTABILIZED THE INDUSTRY WITH LIMITED DAMAGE TO BROADER GROWTH RATE
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite losses following the outbreak of COVID-19, agencies managed to recover significantly in the years that followed, as the wide-scale popularity of team sports and concerts fueled a rebound in the entertainment sector. Growth was bolstered by resounding trends of consumer spending, particularly as pent-up demand during the pandemic lead people to increase their discretionary spending on sports and entertainment venues.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: GREATER DEMAND FROM ACTORS AND CREATIVE ARTISTS FUELS DEMAND FOR AGENTS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A core driver of industry success continues to be interest for agents and managers of creative artists like actors and performers. Many creative artists require the services of agents and managers for exposure and promotion of their career.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: RISE IN SOCIAL MEDIA USE GROWS THE REACH OF THE CORE CLIENT BASE
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: One of the most significant developments in recent years is the acceleration of social media adoption by professional athletes and celebrities. By incorporating social media, agents' core clients are able to advertise, promote and expand their online presence in the eyes of commercial partners and consumers alike to promote their projects.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: POSITIVE ECONOMIC CONDITIONS HELP MAINTAIN GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry has significant dependence on consumer activity and investment into sports, entertainment and recreational activities. Continuous growth in consumer confidence ensures core revenue streams for the industry remain intact.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: GROWTH OF ALTERNATIVE MEDIA FUELS INTERNET CELEBRITY DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As technology continues to accelerate and social media remains a powerful tool to reach consumers, social media is poised to endure enhanced demand from internet celebrities.

Inflationary pressures will be driving up entertainment costs, limiting consumer spending capacity. Consuming sports and entertainment media is easier than ever, but with rising subscription and memberships fees to access content, consumers are contending with rising costs for their basic entertainment.

industry_definition: This industry includes agents and managers who represent or manage creative and performing artists, sports figures, entertainers and public figures. Agents typically focus on finding work for a client and engage in contract negotiation and management for a client, for which they are entitled to a predetermined commission. Managers have a broader role that includes contract negotiation, finding sponsorships and endorsements and other services such as career advice and financial planning.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue from representation of musical groups, singers, songwriters and producers. Many artists in the music industry have seen vast change across their respective industry, with traditional albums and physical covers making way for digital releases and online music streaming services, such as Apple Music and Spotify. Many music artists have also pushed for independent representation as a way of preserving their earnings, with music royalties and commission fees a core reason for this shift that has hurt industry demand in turn.

This market segment generates revenue from agent representation of professional athletes of various sports leagues. The professional athlete market is more difficult to navigate, with year-round sports leagues and tricky rules surrounding collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) across all leagues creating specificity of demand for the industry. There is also a diverse lifespan of the average athlete across different sports, with Major League Baseball (MLB) athletes far less prone to injury compared with a National Football League (NFL) player; this creates an uneven earnings potential as it relates to career lifespan.

This market segment generates revenue from agent representation of artists that work in motion pictures, TV, theatrical productions and live performances. The success of the movie industry enables higher revenue figures on a year-over-year basis and exorbitant growth in advertising expenditure provides movie artists with numerous opportunities to secure lucrative contracts and sponsorship deals. For agents and managers of these artists, the growth of the box office enables a larger revenue stream for movie artists, which can generate a larger percentage of those earnings for the agent. Movies are also less prone to volatility, with many artists negotiating deals on a project-by-project basis and being able to dedicate considerable time in development of the film, boosting revenue into the industry in turn.

market_segmentation.segment: Public speakers, authors and other public figures
market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue from representation services for public speakers, authors, product spokespeople and public figures. Although public speakers generate far less revenue compared with large-scale sports leagues and entertainment hubs, they can generate lofty fees from individual appearances at public events.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue from the sale of representation services to interested clients, with these services provided to clients by a licensed agent.
This product segment generates revenue from the sale of career management services such as legal counsel, employment searching and general career advice.
This product segment generates revenue when structuring client contracts for their core earnings stream, such as a sports contract or record label deal.
Some of the other services offered by the industry involve social media management and outreach for their clients.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As consumer spending increases, consumers are more inclined to spend on discretionary purchases, including for sporting events, films, theater productions, concerts and books. As consumers spend more, companies increase advertising expenditure. Agencies with popular celebrities and athletes will be able to negotiate a better share of advertising expenditures for their clients with notoriety.

business_locations.location_description: Although the Western region does not have the largest population share in the United States, the region has a significant hub and multiple opportunities for celebrities and athletes alike. In states like California, industry establishments benefit from proximity to giant entertainment hubs such as Hollywood and prominent sports organizations such as the Los Angeles Lakers, touching both entertainment and athletic demand, respectively.

The Mid-Atlantic houses a significant share of industry establishments due to its favorable location for international entertainment and sports, respectively. In states like New York, the region is also home to a considerable population presence, particularly for fashion agencies and sports teams such as the New York Knicks and Brooklyn Nets. There is a heightened need for agents and managers alike, with a vast portfolio of investment opportunities fueling the need from celebrities for efficient money management.

The industry has a notable presence in the Southeast due to having the largest share of the population, which expands the opportunities for athletes and celebrities to increase their brand exposure. In states like Florida, large population hubs provide ample opportunities for marketing and sales of entertainment events for industry clients.

Some of the other regions with a significantly smaller industry presence include the Great Lakes, Southwest, New England, Rocky Mountains and the Plains regions. These areas lack notable markets for celebrities and athletes to pursue, with limited population centers further contributing to a small industry presence. The dominance of the Western and Mid-Atlantic regions ensures it becomes difficult for other regions to take over on a per capita basis, skewing the presence toward those areas.

FAQs.question: Are your company's contracts competitive with both direct competitors and alternative forms of entertainment?
FAQs.answer: Agents' commissions are generated through successfully negotiating employment contracts between their clients and employers, with the agent being paid a percentage of the agreed-upon deal.

FAQs.question: How much does your company rely on successful advertising to stand out from the competition?
FAQs.answer: Corporate advertising is essential to sponsorship and endorsement deals that earn large sums for public figures and, by extension, agents and managers.

FAQs.question: How does your company use location to add value and offer unique contracts to your clients?
FAQs.answer: The industry's biggest agents are based in the world's entertainment capitals, where their clients are usually based, like New York City, London and Los Angeles.

FAQs.question: Have you considered investing in acquisitions? What measures have you taken to expand operations?
FAQs.answer: Many of the industry's larger agencies have participated in mergers and acquisitions to continue expanding their client base. Expansion can increase revenue from more clients while also expanding opportunities for clients.

FAQs.question: What new communication technologies have you implemented during the period? How have you used technology to improve relationships with clients?
FAQs.answer: Companies invest in the latest and most sophisticated methods of communication, like wireless application protocol mobile phones and laptop computers with remote internet access. Ensuring strong lines of communication can improve relationships with clients.

FAQs.question: What technologies do you use to keep operations running smoothly? What other technologies have you implemented?
FAQs.answer: Products such as finance-managing software can be incredibly useful to clients managing many clients at once. Implementing technology to manage clients can improve efficiencies and enable companies to keep up with changing trends.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that impact the industry?
FAQs.answer: Operators are subject to and must have knowledge of numerous regulations, including those about licensing, fair contracts and salaries.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with salary caps that may allow your company to negotiate contracts for its clients?
FAQs.answer: Salary caps, particularly those for professional sports, change yearly, and may present an opportunity for agents to negotiate higher salaries for their clients.

FAQs.question: Is your company's profit margin in step with major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Industry profit has wavered due to price-based competition caused by celebrities, athletes and public figures who have either suffered from fewer projects or who had elected to terminate entirely their relationships with agents and managers.

FAQs.question: Do you have a high retention rate among clients under contract? What measures have you taken to improve client retention?
FAQs.answer: Long-term client relations and contracts can be especially beneficial to industry servicers, especially as continually high budgets for major blockbusters and media productions enable agents and managers to help their clients sign more lucrative contracts.

FAQs.question: Do you offer a diverse range of services? Do you cater any specific market with the services you offer?
FAQs.answer: Agents and managers must display a variety of skills and understand the unique marketing potential of each client to succeed.

FAQs.question: How do you advertise your services? What are some other promotional methods that you use?
FAQs.answer: Agents and managers must promote celebrity figures to enhance the client's brand and market their talents for future projects. Agents rely on word-of-mouth marketing to attract additional clients.

FAQs.question: How does your coverage compare with that of your competitors? Are there some areas in which it is harder to provide service? How does your company compete in areas of higher concentration?
FAQs.answer: Global corporations require widely recognized personalities to endorse products on an international scale while some endorsements are on a more regional scale.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the Consumer Confidence Index? How can you adapt when the Consumer Confidence Index declines?
FAQs.answer: As consumers gain confidence, they feel more secure in their finances and are therefore more likely to spend freely.

FAQs.question: Is corporate advertising essential to sponsorship and endorsement deals?
FAQs.answer: Corporations' willingness and ability to advertise is essential to the health of downstream industries. Total advertising expenditure rises when corporate profit expands.

FAQs.question: Which clients are most and least susceptible to economic shocks? How much do you rely on strong performance within the entertainment industries?
FAQs.answer: Growing levels of per capita disposable income give consumers more flexibility to purchase discretionary items like sports and entertainment tickets, as well as products that are endorsed and sponsored by public figures.
